@ptone mixins are normal python classes and have the normal sort of Python inheritance behavior. Mixins just have a cool title for a class that is designed to not store any data but to modify the behavior of an object

@bryan dang - though, i guess it is easy as running a few tests
problem would come about when you had 2 apps that use jquery and you end up loading jquery twice from different app folders
seems like --compress-js on the collectstatic management command would be where that should be added
so long as django-compress runs AFTER collect static, perhaps it is fine
*virtual applause*
@ashchristopher As far as I know, they haven't updated it to honor STATIC_URL over MEDIA_URL yet. django-css is the same way.
no, might not be a bad idea to try
seems like a best practices would be to do it like templates where you put the app name under the static folder

I was talking about going straight to production.  If you aren't careful you end up download the the same js file from multiple apps, so things like jquery might not belong in the static/appname folder
@mark0978 Right, you have to run this before deployment.
http://www.djangopackages.com/grids/g/asset-managers/

As a user of noscript, I haven't tried using jquery from google because of the fact it would require 2 exceptions to allow the js to run (I think, one from my site, one for the js from google).  I've been using jquery with a Far Future Expires and serving up the file myself.
Thanks, Jacob!  Great presentation.
Has the core django-storages been updated with Malcom Tredennick's work yet?
The use case for HTTP-only cookies is so that hostile Javascript code (say, from cross-site scripting) can't spoof your session cookies.
